nodes.text: State-level economic policy uncertainty can be quantified with newspaper-based monthly indexes and these state-level uncertainty measures matter for state economic performance and vary systematically with elections, national events, and pandemic-era policies

We construct three monthly state-level EPU indexes per state: EPU-S (state and local sources), EPU-N (national and international sources), and EPU-C (composite), using digital archives of about 3,500 local newspapers
Index construction flags articles that mention an economy term, an uncertainty term, and policy terms tailored to national or state scope, then normalizes raw ratios to a 2006-2019 baseline per state

State and local policy matters are major sources of measured state-level policy uncertainty; before COVID about 50% of composite EPU articles mentioned only national policy, 30% only state/local, and 20% both, and after March 2020 the share from state/local rose substantially

Election timing and closeness drive EPU: presidential elections raise EPU-N substantially and close presidential contests raise EPU-N by about 60 percent; close gubernatorial contests raise EPU-S by about 35 percent
Selected national and international events (9-11, debt-ceiling crisis, Brexit, Trump 2016, federal shutdowns) produced large one-month increases in EPU-N across most states
The COVID-19 pandemic produced huge increases in both EPU-N and EPU-S, with average EPU-N reaching 2.7 times its pre-COVID peak and average EPU-S more than four times its previous peak

During the pandemic the primary locus of policy uncertainty shifted toward state and local sources: the cross-state average ratio EPU-S/EPU-N rose from 0.65 pre-pandemic to 1.1 in March 2020â€“June 2021

State-level VAR models using pre-COVID data show that upward innovations to own-state composite EPU foreshadow higher unemployment, lower employment, and weaker housing permits, peaking about one year after the shock

Newspaper sample covers roughly 3,500 local daily and weekly papers, median 49 papers per state-month, sample back to 1985 for some states and fully covered since 2006; all indexes and replication code are publicly available
The composition of sources varies widely across states and time: examples include Alaska (high EPU-S share) versus DC (high EPU-N share)
Close elections and major national events produce heterogeneous but often large cross-state EPU spikes documented by month-on-month log changes in indexed values
Pandemic-era increases in state-level EPU are more strongly associated with the stringency of government-mandated lockdown orders than with COVID deaths per capita

Upward own-state EPU shocks and upward EPU shocks in contiguous states both foreshadow weaker own-state activity; VARs with spatial BEPU show border-state shocks have similar-shaped unemployment responses to own-state shocks

Policy uncertainty shocks account for a modest share (about 10% at 30-month horizon) of forecast error variance for state unemployment, but occasional large synchronized EPU spikes can produce sizable unemployment movements in specific states

During the pandemic states with stricter lockdowns experienced larger increases in unemployment relative to 2019, and conditional on lockdown stringency larger increases in EPU-C are associated with larger unemployment increases
